Description: A flask in the form of Bes seated on a cylindrical stand with top and bottom mouldings. He is naked and sits with the soles of his feet together, and with his hands resting on his thighs. The mouth of the flask is lost, together with his plumes and probably a handle or handles. A voluted tendril survives at the left side of his forehead. The rear is plain, except for his buttocks. There is a base-ring, within which is an incuse broken-barred alpha, probably formed in the mould. Three-piece mould. Reduced fabric: grey Nile silt with some mica; coated with a black slip: Memphis Black Ware.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Acquired at Damanhur. Ptolemaic, about second century BC. Comparanda: Same mould-series, perhaps same mould as registration no. 1883,0802.2. Not unlike, same fabric: Edgar 1911: pl. xxv:26315; 'LIMC' iii (2): pl. 83, Bes 67b, left.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3093)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
